content:
(Note: This stream was split from Bimodules vs Spans: Puzzle 1 and Bimodules vs Spans: Puzzle 2. Some comments here refer to those streams and contains links to the respective posts.)

Puzzle 3: What’s a bimodule of a pair of monoid objects in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop?

[Edit: This solution is completely wrong. See Attempt #2 below.]

A bimodule would be a set XXX with compatible left and right actions.

Let
{}
L=End(X)×X\sout{L = \mathsf{End}(X)\times X}L=End(X)×X​
{}
and
{}
R=Endop(X)×X\sout{R = \mathsf{End^{op}}(X)\times X}R=Endop(X)×X​
{}
so that the actions can be written
{}
αL:L→XandαR:R→X.\sout{\alpha_L: L\to X\quad\text{and}\quad\alpha_R: R\to X.}αL​:L→XandαR​:R→X.​
{}

Together, the actions form a cospan
{}
L→X←R\sout{L\rightarrow X\leftarrow R}L→X←R
{}
and pulling this back enforces their compatibility resulting in a span
{}
L←L×XR→R.\sout{L\leftarrow L\times_X R\rightarrow R.}L←L×X​R→R.​
{}
We can go one step further by forming the spans
{}
End(X)←L→X\sout{\mathsf{End}(X)\leftarrow L\rightarrow X}End(X)←L→X​
{}
X←R→Endop(X)\sout{X\leftarrow R\rightarrow \mathsf{End^{op}}(X)}X←R→Endop(X)​
{}
so that the composition of these two spans is
{}
End(X)←L×XR→Endop(X).\sout{\mathsf{End}(X)\leftarrow L\times_X R\rightarrow\mathsf{End^{op}}(X).}End(X)←L×X​R→Endop(X).​

Ahh Eric, check what monoidal product is in play in Setop\mathbf{Set}^{\mathrm{op}}Setop!! A "monoid object in [monoidal category C\mathcal{C}C with monoidal product ⊗\otimes⊗ and monoidal unit III]" needs maps M⊗M→MM \otimes M \to MM⊗M→M and I→MI \to MI→M

John Baez said:

A set is a monoid object in the monoidal category (Setop,+)(\mathsf{Set}^{\mathrm{op}}, +)(Setop,+).

We can define bimodules for monoid objects in any monoidal category.

A span of sets is a bimodule in (Setop,+)(\mathsf{Set}^{\mathrm{op}},+)(Setop,+).

John mentioned already what monoidal product you should be using here in the message quoted above :wink:

Hi Morgan :wave:

I'm afraid I don't follow :thinking:

I was going by what the original post said:

Let’s work in the category Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop, where a morphism f:S→Tf:S→Tf:S→T is a function from TTT to SSS. This is a monoidal category with ××× as its tensor product. So, we can talk about monoid objects in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop.
Hmmm, does ×\times× there mean the product in Set\mathbf{Set}Set or in Setop\mathbf{Set}^\mathrm{op}Setop?

I certainly made some mistakes (and hope to learn from them), but I don't think I got that wrong :sweat_smile:

This comment makes me think we really want ×\times× for Setop.\mathsf{Set^{op}}.Setop.

So I was using (Setop,×,∗)(\mathsf{Set^{op}}, \times, *)(Setop,×,∗) (where ∗={∙}* = \{\bullet\}∗={∙}, i.e. the terminal set).

The dual problem with (Set,⊔,∅)(\mathsf{Set},\sqcup,\emptyset)(Set,⊔,∅) is also interesting :blush:

Eric Forgy said:

Puzzle 1: What’s a monoid object in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop?

The "object" is a set XXX, but for this to be a monoid object, we need a multiplication

μ:X×X→X.\mu: X\times X\to X.μ:X×X→X.

and a unit

η:∗→X\eta: *\to Xη:∗→X

satisfying the conditions. I don't think the answer is complete without specifying those :thinking:

Attempt #1: Before looking at Puzzle #2

I think a multiplication X×X→XX\times X\to XX×X→X in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop is a function X→X×XX\to X\times XX→X×X in Set\mathsf{Set}Set and the only function that would make sense to me is
{}
x↦(x,x)∈X×X.x\mapsto (x,x)\in X\times X.x↦(x,x)∈X×X.
{}
A unit ∗→X*\to X∗→X in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop is a function X→∗X\to *X→∗ in Set\mathsf{Set}Set and that is unique since ∗*∗ is terminal.

A quick doodle confirms these satisfy associativity and unit laws.

Right! And the really cool part is that this is the only possible choice of maps μ:X→X×X\mu: X \to X \times Xμ:X→X×X and η:X→1\eta: X \to 1η:X→1 obeying (co)associativity and the (co)unit laws. (We usually put the word "co" in here since the maps are going backwards.) So while in Set\mathsf{Set}Set you need to specify μ\muμ and η\etaη to say how we are treating our set XXX as a monoid, in Setop\mathsf{Set}^{\mathrm{op}}Setop you don't: there's only one choice!

Morgan Rogers (he/him) said:

John Baez said:

A set is a monoid object in the monoidal category (Setop,+)(\mathsf{Set}^{\mathrm{op}}, +)(Setop,+).

We can define bimodules for monoid objects in any monoidal category.

A span of sets is a bimodule in (Setop,+)(\mathsf{Set}^{\mathrm{op}},+)(Setop,+).

John mentioned already what monoidal product you should be using here in the message quoted above :wink:

But my remark was probably confusing, because the coproduct + in Setop\mathsf{Set}^{\mathrm{op}}Setop is exactly what we usually call the product ×\times× in Set\mathsf{Set}Set. Anyway, this is the monoidal product I want: the coproduct in Setop\mathsf{Set}^{\mathrm{op}}Setop, which we should probably write as ×\times× because it's the familiar set

X×Y={(x,y):x∈X,y∈Y}X \times Y = \{(x,y) : x \in X, y \in Y\}X×Y={(x,y):x∈X,y∈Y}

which is the product in Set\mathsf{Set}Set.
It was my mistake, then, not Eric's! Thanks for clarifying.

Sure!

Anyway, Eric was completely correct in his first attempt to solve Puzzle 1.

Here's a more general way to think about this puzzle. In any monoidal category where the monoidal structure is given by coproduct, every object xxx becomes a monoid in a unique way.

The unit η:0→x\eta: 0 \to xη:0→x is unique because 000 is initial. The left and right unit laws force μ:x+x→x\mu: x + x \to xμ:x+x→x to be the codiagonal or 'fold' map ∇:x+x→x\nabla: x + x \to x∇:x+x→x.
Δ\DeltaΔ is associative so xxx becomes a monoid this way. In fact it's commutative.
Even better, the maps η\etaη are Δ\DeltaΔ are natural, every morphism in our category becomes a morphism of commutative monoids.
Btw, I've the split the original stream into 3 streams, one for each puzzle, so this is now the stream for Puzzle 3 :blush:

My answer above for Puzzle 3 is completely wrong, so starting over :face_palm:

Given a monoid object AAA, i.e. a set, a left AAA-module is a set XXX together with a function
{}
αL:A×X→X.\sout{\alpha_L: A\times X\to X.}αL​:A×X→X.​
{}
Similarly, a right BBB-module is a set XXX together with a function
{}
αR:X×B→X.\sout{\alpha_R:X\times B\to X.}αR​:X×B→X.​

Attempt #2

Given monoid objects AAA and BBB, an (A,B)(A,B)(A,B)-bimodule is a set XXX together with compatible functions
{}
αL:A×X→X.\sout{\alpha_L: A\times X\to X.}αL​:A×X→X.​
{}
and
{}
αR:X×B→X.\sout{\alpha_R:X\times B\to X.}αR​:X×B→X.​
{}
These functions form a cospan
{}
A×X→X←X×B\sout{A\times X\rightarrow X\leftarrow X\times B}A×X→X←X×B​
{}
that can be pulled back (enforcing compatibility) forming a span
{}
A×X←(A×X)×X(X×B)→X×B.\sout{A\times X\leftarrow (A\times X)\times_X (X\times B)\rightarrow X\times B.}A×X←(A×X)×X​(X×B)→X×B.​
{}
Hence, an (A,B)(A,B)(A,B)-bimodule XXX in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop is a span
{}
A×X←(A×X)×X(X×B)→X×B.\sout{A\times X\leftarrow (A\times X)\times_X (X\times B)\rightarrow X\times B.}A×X←(A×X)×X​(X×B)→X×B.​

Note this means the answer to Puzzle #2 is also a span of sets.

Let B=∗B = *B=∗, then
{}
∗×B≅B\sout{*\times B\cong B}∗×B≅B​
{}
and
{}
S×XX≅S\sout{S\times_X X\cong S}S×X​X≅S​
{}
so that a (A,∗)(A,*)(A,∗)-bimodule is a span
{}
A×X←idA×X→αLX,\sout{A\times X\overset{\mathsf{id}}{\leftarrow} A\times X\overset{\alpha_L}\rightarrow X,}A×X←idA×X→αL​X,​
{}
but this is a left AAA-module so a left AAA-module is an (A,∗)(A,*)(A,∗)-bimodule.

Similarly, a right BBB-module is a (∗,B)(*,B)(∗,B)-bimodule.

Furthermore, an (A,B)(A,B)(A,B)-bimodule is the composition of a left AAA-module, i.e. (A,∗)(A,*)(A,∗)-bimodule, with a right BBB-module, i.e. (∗,B)(*,B)(∗,B)-bimodule.
